Message.Title: It's an outrage...where my Twinkies
Message.Msg: ** Hostess Brands disclosed plans on Friday to liquidate its assets and lay off most of its 18,500 workers** How can a couple of hedgefunds do this to these hard working union folks during the holidays...what about the children. I don't know about you but this kind of capitialist greed needs to end, and it needs to end now. These money changers on WS didn't build that, it was the collective society that made it possible for this company to prosper. I say that the Justice Department needs to force these rats to continue funding this company until the Obama administration can step in and redistribute the stock and bonds to the unions. This company needs to be bailed and the union jobs that will be lost...If we taxpayers can bailout those fatcats bankers we can sure as hell help these hard working union working men and women. Call, email you representative and tell them to save this iconic company from those greedy 1%ers, and remind them that the folks spoke in November 2012...and that elections matter! Hostess Brands disclosed plans on Friday to liquidate its assets and lay off most of its 18,500 workersThe End of Hostess as We Know It Failing to persuade striking employees to return to work, Hostess Brands disclosed plans on Friday to liquidate its assets and lay off most of its 18,500 workers, bringing the 82-year-old maker of Wonder Bread and Twinkies to the end of its line. The painful decision to wind down the Irving, Texas.-based private company follows a nationwide strike that Hostess said severely constrained its operations. Hostess said delivery of its products, which include Ding Dongs and CupCakes, will continue and its retail stores will keep their lights on for several days to sell already-baked products. “We deeply regret the necessity of today’s decision, but we do not have the financial resources to weather an extended nationwide strike,” Hostess CEO Gregory Rayburn said in a statement. As a result of the liquidation, Hostess said it will “move promptly” to lay off “most” of its 18,500 employees and focus on “selling its assets to the highest bidders.” The company will now be forced to close its 33 bakeries, 565 distribution centers, 5,500 delivery routes and 570 bakery outlet stores throughout the U.S. The Bakery, Confectionery, Tobacco Workers and Grain Millers International Union pushed back against the Rayburn blaming the liquidation on the unions.
